name: chatgpt_env_marine_atex22_gdb_fz
description: [ChatGPT Env] Offshore ATEX22 + GDB FZ ‚Üí BLOCK (C3 insufficient), suggest RF/SF
query: GDB 600x600 FZ offshore in ATEX 22 area.

turns.content: GDB 600x600 FZ offshore in ATEX 22 area.

This GDB filter configuration is blocked for your offshore application due to the marine environment. The GDB housing has a C2 corrosion class and single-wall uninsulated construction, which does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine environments. Salt spray will accelerate corrosion of the C3-rated galvanized steel (FZ) housing.Additionally, outdoor installation introduces the risk of condensation on non-insulated metal surfaces. To address these issues, I recommend a multi-stage filtration system using the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p, which is approved for marine environments. The GDMI housing has a C2 corrosion class.To protect the GDMI, I've included a GDP Planfiltersk√•p as a protector stage. This configuration also addresses the explosive atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22) by ensuring proper grounding and the use of anti-static filter media to prevent spark ignition.To finalize the configuration, I need two details:First, what is the reference airflow for the system?Second, to assess the risk of condensation, I need the minimum expected ambient temperature and typical relative humidity at the installation site.High humidity reduces carbon adsorption efficiency. Keep relative humidity below 70% for optimal performance.

gemini.explanation: The system correctly blocked the unsuitable GDB housing for the offshore application but failed significantly on the product data for the recommended alternative. It stated that the GDMI housing has a C2 corrosion class, whereas the PDF explicitly states it is C4 (ZM). This factual error undermines the engineering logic, as replacing a C2 housing with another 'C2' housing would not solve the corrosion issue.

dimension_explanations.correctness: The system claims GDMI has a C2 corrosion class, but PDF Page 11 states 'Korrosivitets klass C4' for standard GDMI (ZM).
dimension_explanations.completeness: The system asks relevant follow-up questions regarding airflow and ambient conditions.
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly blocks the GDB FZ configuration for offshore use due to corrosion and condensation risks.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: The logic is contradictory: it blocks GDB for being C2/corrosion-prone but then recommends GDMI while incorrectly claiming it is also C2.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Respects the environmental constraints by blocking the GDB, though the justification for the alternative contained errors.

strengths: Correctly identified GDB FZ as unsuitable for offshore/marine environments
Correctly identified the need for insulation (GDMI) in outdoor/offshore settings
Appropriate clarification requests for airflow and humidity
weaknesses: Factually incorrect data for GDMI (claimed C2, PDF says C4)
Contradictory reasoning (recommending a product it claimed was C2 to solve a corrosion problem)
pdf_citations: GDMI: 'Korrosivitets klass C4' (PDF p.11) - System incorrectly claimed C2

openai.explanation: The system correctly flags that a standard GDB in FZ is not appropriate for offshore/marine exposure, but it makes multiple factual errors about corrosion classes and invents ATEX suitability/approvals not supported by the catalog. It also recommends GDMI as ‚Äúapproved for marine‚Äù while simultaneously mis-stating its corrosion class, and it introduces hygiene/leakage claims that are not relevant/accurate for this product context.

dimension_explanations.correctness: PDF shows GDB is for inomhusbruk and typically FZ with korrosivitetsklass C2 and GDB 600x600 has Fl√∂de 3400 m¬≥/h, but the response incorrectly calls FZ ‚ÄúC3-rated‚Äù and claims GDMI is ‚Äúapproved for marine‚Äù while stating GDMI is C2 (PDF indicates GDMI is usually ZM/AZ with korrosivitetsklass C4).
dimension_explanations.completeness: It asks for airflow and ambient conditions, but does not resolve the core request (ATEX Zone 22 execution details, material selection for offshore, and what housing family in this range is actually suitable) and provides no viable catalog-backed alternative for offshore/ATEX.
dimension_explanations.safety: It mentions grounding/anti-static media, but gives an implicit path to ATEX compliance without confirming certified ATEX design (housing, gaskets, earthing points, documentation), which is a critical safety gap for Zone 22.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and consultative, with clear warnings and follow-up questions.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Reasoning is internally inconsistent (blocks GDB for C2 then recommends GDMI while calling it C2) and mixes unrelated claims (hygiene requirements) with marine corrosion concerns without a clear, standard-based chain.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Correctly blocks GDB for offshore exposure as an engineering judgment, but violates catalog constraints by asserting marine approval/ATEX suitability and incorrect corrosion classes/material performance.

strengths: Appropriately cautious about offshore/marine corrosion and condensation risk for single-wall housings.
Requests key missing design inputs (airflow, ambient temperature/RH) before final sizing.
weaknesses: Multiple catalog/data inaccuracies and contradictions on corrosion class/material (FZ C3 vs C2; GDMI C2 vs C4).
ATEX Zone 22 guidance is not handled rigorously (no confirmation of certified ATEX execution; implies compliance via grounding/media alone).

content_segments.text: This GDB filter configuration is blocked for your offshore application due to the marine environment. The GDB housing has a C2 corrosion class and single-wall uninsulated construction, which does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine environments. Salt spray will accelerate corrosion of the C3-rated galvanized steel (FZ) housing.

Additionally, outdoor installation introduces the risk of condensation on non-insulated metal surfaces. To address these issues, I recommend a multi-stage filtration system using the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p, which is approved for marine environments. The GDMI housing has a C2 corrosion class.

To protect the GDMI, I've included a GDP Planfiltersk√•p as a protector stage. This configuration also addresses the explosive atmosphere (ATEX Zone 22) by ensuring proper grounding and the use of anti-static filter media to prevent spark ignition.
To finalize the configuration, I need two details:
First, what is the reference airflow for the system?
Second, to assess the risk of condensation, I need the minimum expected ambient temperature and typical relative humidity at the installation site.
High humidity reduces carbon adsorption efficiency. Keep relative humidity below 70% for optimal performance.
